User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:6.0.2) Gecko/20110902 Firefox/6.0.2 SeaMonkey/2.3.3
Build ID: 20110902180055

Steps to reproduce:

Reply to a message, cut irrelevant parts from the quoted text and start typing below the quoted text.


Actual results:

While typing, the area around the "current position" where I'm typing flickers. It looks as something is drawn, then wiped-out and then drawn again for every key I press.



Expected results:

I prefer non-flickering text. :-)

Expected results:

I too see this frequently for one machine on 64-bit Windows 7 (NVIDIA graphics card) since the TB 6.0.x versions (don't recall if I saw it with 5.0 already), but not on another machine with ATI card. The important part in order to reproduce the flickering is that one has to delete part of the message first before the issue appears.

Also interesting, I don't see it in the composition window for SeaMonkey 2.5a2 on the same machine where I see it for Thunderbird, thus something must be different between those.

Direct2d is disabled in all setups.

comments.raw_text:
Yes, also seen with 6.0.2 in safe mode, both plain-text and HTML composition modes affected.

Bert may have made different observations (if yes, please state so), but it predominantly seems to happen with long messages replied to that require the scroll bar to appear in the editor. Then, deleting all or part of the message makes the scroll bar disappear again, and typing shows the flickering effect in the current line which is typed.

comments.raw_text:
I'll try to give as much info as possible:

- I never use HTML composition, only plain text
- I'm using a thinkpad W701 which indeed also runs Windows 7 64 bit and has a NVidia chipset.
- I tried the above mentioned sequence of steps and that's indeed the way to reproduce it. If I trim a long quoted message such that the scrollbar disappears and then start typing the problem appears. Doing the same sequence of steps on a short message behaves normally. As far as I can tell the only difference between a long and a short message is the appearance of the scrollbar.
